description.narrative: The overall objectives of the “Tikambe! Let’s Talk! Natulande! Alubulele! are that young people in Lusaka, Central, and Western Provinces are empowered to demand greater government accountability in relation to SRHR service provision and know how to uptake healthier SRH behaviours.

Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The Tikambe project has produced some very good results in relation to the overall objective of young people demanding greater accountability for SRHR services as well as taking on healthier SRH beahviours. In a number of instances, targets were exceeded. For example, the endline survey to measure project impact showed that 54% of the target population of 14 to 24 year olds in the four districts were exposed to Tikambe radio, Facebook or TV programmes. This translates into an estimated reach of 313,500 young people, which exceeds the initial target of 100,000 young people. In terms of the uptake of healthier SRH behaviours, those regularly exposed to Tikambe (TV, radio or Facebook, or a combination of these) were shown in the endline survey to be significantly more likely to report adopting healthier SRHR behaviours, thus making them less vulnerable to SRH risks. This included visiting a clinic, getting tested for an STI, talking to a partner about preventing STIs and getting treatment for HIV. In terms of accountability, an example of a good result, related to improving SRH services for young people is the strengthened coordination and adoption of a standard referral tool by both the Ministry of Health and Ministry of Education offices at district, clinic and school levels, including by the district guidance and counselling units and district adolescent health units. Another example is the conctruction and the speedy completion of structures and spaces to be used for youth friendly services in response to recommendations made by young people during their respective dialogue meetings. A case study recorded from Katuba in Mkushi shows that through the self-assessment process and consequent dialogue meeting, an incomplete clinic structure was completed for a youth friendly corner within the agreed time as a result of the accountability process in the project. Other highlights of results from Tikambe include the following: ? Of those regularly reached, 31% said that they had done something differently in terms of their SRHR as a result of Tikambe. This included talking openly about SRH issues, using modern contraceptives, getting information on SRH issues and talking about Tikambe with friends and or family and parents. ? The vast majority of those exposed to Tikambe (TV, radio or Facebook, or a combination of these) 'agreed' or 'very much agreed' that the Tikambe programme played a role in holding to account government (93%) and local decision makers (94%) for providing sexual and reproductive health services.? Overall 82% of all respondents in the endline survey said they felt either 'a little bit' or 'very supported' by the key people in their life and community around SRHR issues (that is matters related to sex, relationships, pregnancy, STIs). Regression analysis showed that, when controlling for other factors, those who were regularly reached by Tikambe (TV, radio or Facebook, or a combination of these) were 1.8 times more likely to say that they felt ‘very supported’ by the key people in their life and community around various SRH issues than those not regularly reached by Tikambe. ? Regression analysis (controlling for other factors), showed that those who were regularly reached by Tikambe (TV, radio or Facebook, or a combination of these) were 2.1 times more likely to have visited a health centre/clinic to discuss issues related to sexual and reproductive health in the last 12 months than those not regularly reached by Tikambe. ? The endline survey showed that Tikambe has had a significant impact on knowledge and awareness of various SRH issues among audiences. This was across a number of areas including contraception and HIV testing. In terms of outputs, a few highlights are:o 508 interactive radio magazine programmes produced and aired across four partner stations.o 41 Radio Drama programmes produced and broadcast across four radio partners.o Twelve trainings delivered on SRHR, Drama and PSA production.o The Tikambe page has now surpassed 140,000 likes (17th biggest page in Zambia).o 7,600 lessons conducted with in and out of school youths on SRHR and life skills.o 25 clinics in three provinces providing improved youth friendly SRHR services.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
